198001.name: Mustache Dandy
198001.description: In ヒゲダンディ (a.k.a. Mustache Dandy), players need to determine the state of their facial hair in relation to the mustaches and beards of all the other players, but players cannot see the hair on their own face, so they'll need to use cues from others to figure out exactly how dandy they look.

198002.name: DnDizzle: Dragons in the Hood
198002.description:
User summary:

Character creation involves selecting a Class (Doc, Freestyler, Jacker, Street Magician, Thug, or Trigger Man), distributing a points pool into Stats (Attributes), including Agility, Brains, Might, and Soul. Characters select a number of "Skillz" (Skills) and distribute points into them. Characters also have and gain Abilities as they gain levels. A variety of derived attributes are also calculated. Opposed action resolution involves a modified 2d6 roll compared against a target.

The fairly typical game system is coupled with a humorous and "over the top" quasi-fantasy setting with numerous major elements derived from the "gangsta" scene.

198003.description:
Dark Deeds is a darkly humorous card game of skullduggery and suspicion for 2 to 5 players. In Dark Deeds players take the role of minions in service to a powerful, mysterious, and clearly villainous, patron. The Patron wants deeds of infamy, violence and coercion committed and you are the ones who must avoid the authorities, the do-gooders and, most of all, each other to perform them. Rich rewards beckon, along with horrific punishments for failure. So are you the kind of malevolent minion the patron needs?

There’s a ‘street’ deck for the minion’s prospective targets – clerics, artisans, and merchants and their protective guards from the city watch. Then there’s a ‘tavern’ deck with potentially useful loot and plot cards to help the minions get the job done. The implacable hand of evil is revealed by the nemesis cards in the street deck – princes, politicians, and do-gooders the player’s evil patron wants eliminated. The tavern deck includes ‘Dark Deeds’, specific missions to take out particular nemeses (that’s the plural of nemesis in case you’re wondering). Picking up a Dark Deed is a very mixed blessing. A rich reward is earned for completing it, but it can’t be discarded and the patron will exact a heavy price for any incomplete Dark Deeds held at the end of the game.

The masterful touch is how the street deck is laid out to create a constantly moving scene of different characters. Each turn the street moves along, the card closest to the end leaves and everyone else shuffles up with empty spaces filled from the deck. Minions enter from one end of the street and have to get past any intervening guards to reach their targets.
198003.name: Dark Deeds
boardgamepodcastepisode: The Polyhedron Collider Cast Episode 4
The Polyhedron Collider Cast Episode 6

198004.name: Kiyoshikenga抜 Kenai
198004.description:
聖剣ガ抜ケナイ (a.k.a. Kiyoshikenga抜 Kenai) is a semi-cooperative battling game in which players simultaneously reveal a card from their hand to collectively try to pull a sword from a stone. You don't want to waste your strength, though! If the total strength is within the winning range, then whoever played the lowest card wins — unless more than one person played a card of the same value in which case the next lowest person wins.

If you pulled too hard, then the player who played the highest number wins the round — unless, of course, more than one person did the same.

Whoever wins the most rounds wins the game!

198005.name: Revanche
198005.description: Revanche is a soccer-themed card game in which players take possession of the ball and generate scoring opportunities by playing matching cards. The referee dice award direct kicks, corner kicks and penalty kicks, but also hand out yellow and red cards! The game also incorporates aspects such as substitutions, additional time, extra time, and penalty shootouts. The player who scores the most goals wins!

198007.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 692)
198007.description:
Triage 101: Five Ways to Get Players Unstuck
The Hidden Structure of Russian Folk Tales

198008.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 691)
198008.description: Space Opera Part 3: Making it Personal

198009.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 690)
198009.description: How to fill in the blanks - drawing maps Dungeon World style

198010.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 689)
198010.description: GM Burnout: Tips for Prevention and Recovery

198011.name: Trick Question: The Clever Game of Quick Wit – Served With a Twist!
198011.description:
Trick Question is the party game where things never mean quite what they seem! Every question has a trick up its sleeve, and it's a race to outsmart your friends. Will you grab the US! Totem and solve the riddle yourself, or reach for the THEM! Totem and put the other team in the hot seat? Packed with 400 brainteasers that will keep everyone guessing (and laughing), Trick Question is the next hit board game for clever people!

Sample Question: What is the difference between here and there?
Answer: The letter T

198012.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 688)
198012.description: The Card Game - the fastest way to map your kingdom with adventure sites

198013.name: Monster Hunter Generations
videogamehonor: 2015 Japan Game Awards Best Unreleased Game Winner
2016 Golden Joystick Best Handheld/Mobile Game of the Year Nominee
2016 Golden Joystick Nintendo Console Game of the Year Nominee
2016 Japan Game Awards Game of the Year Winner
2016 The Game Awards Best Mobile/Handheld Game of the Year Nominee
198013.description:
Monster Hunter Generations features gameplay similar to past titles in the series. The player assumes the role of a hunter who embarks on quests to hunt dangerous creatures. The game will have four new signature monsters along with a number of past flagship monsters.

Source: Wikipedia, "[en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monster_Hunter_Generations Monster Hunter Generations]", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

198014.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 599)
198014.description:
Three line cultures: how to inject races and factions with flavor

User summary:

This "lost" issue chronologically was published "out of order", between 687 and 688.

198017.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 685)
198017.description: Space Opera Part 2: Building the Setting Core Elements

198019.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 683)
198019.description: Countdown to the apocalypse: six ways to raise the stakes

198020.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 682)
198020.description: What is space opera? And how do you make it?

198021.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 681)
198021.description: How to create your kingdom's history

198022.description: Creating campaign outlines for the first time

198023.description: Four ways to load Checkhov's gun in your games

198024.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 678)
198024.description: Better roleplaying - how to create a great character concept

198025.description:
Promo card for Star Realms.

Battle Barge
Star Empire Ship
Cost: 4
Ability: Target opponent discards a card. If you have two or more bases in play, gain 3 combat and you may return target base from play to its owner's hand.
198025.name: Star Realms: Battle Barge Promo Card

198027.description:
Promo card for Star Realms.

Breeding Site
Star Blob Base
Cost: 4
Ability: If you played a base this turn (including this one), gain 5 Combat.
198027.name: Star Realms: Breeding Site Promo Card

198028.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 676)
198028.description: A three step modern haunting generator

198029.description:
デザインタウン：未開地 (Design Town: Wilderness) is a standalone expansion for Design Town (a.k.a. Flip City), a deck-building game in which you have no hand at all, but instead play cards directly from the top of your deck.

A turn consists of two phases: card playing and building. Players play cards directly from the top of their deck and may choose to continue unless they have three cry-face icons in play, which ends their turn immediately. When they choose to stop, they move to the building phase.

During the building phase, a player can use the coins gained from their previously played cards to buy a new card or to upgrade a card in their personal discard pile. To upgrade a card, pay the cost and flip it over; upgraded cards remain in the discard pile.

Since all cards in this game are double-sided, be careful not to flip them over accidentally when placing cards into your discard pile or when shuffling your deck.

Whenever a player gains eight or more VP during a single card playing phase, the player wins immediately!
198029.name: Design Town: Wilderness

198030.name: Nantucket Sleighride
198030.description:
Or, the Moby Dick Roleplaying Game

From the introduction:

What is a Nantucket Sleighride? It is the term for a whaling boat being dragged across the waves at 25 mph by an enraged sperm whale.
...
You and your fellow whalers will undergo a four-act play; each act comprising of three scenes. And then wrap up the story with a final epilogue. All of the instructions are printed on the game cards you will be using. You will also need a regular deck of 52 playing cards; some pens and perhaps some paper for notes.

User summary:

The game uses a stripped pack of French playing cards and also a custom pack of cards that are provided in the document as print-and-play components.

198031.name: Wolf in the Village
198031.description:
Wolf in the Village is a Werewolf-style game.
"Wolf in the village" is a story that kill a werewolf lurking in the village.
Players separate to the villager side and werewolf side, and win by the vote to lynch.
The villagers often have specialists competing against wolves. For example: Seer, Hunter, Medium, Assasin etc.
Wolves are not the only ones lurking in the village. Human Traitor(mad man), neither ally Fox etc ...
Your bravery leads to victory.

English rules
You can get english rules PDF here!
http://wolfinthevillage.dirtylabor.com/english/Villagers%20G...

*Object of the game*
"wolf in the Village" is a Werewolf-style game.
You can play with 2 types of rules:
Normal werewolf-style rule and One-night rule.

**Werewolf game rule

For 6 to 20 Players + 1 Moderator.
According to the number of players, and then add other cards.
Do not use Teru-Teru card.

For the Werewolves : Kill all of the Villagers.
For the Villagers : Kill all of the Werewolves and the Fox.
For the Fox : Survive until the end of the game.

**One-night rule
More speedily play rules.
Playing time: 10 to 20 min.
For 4 to 12 Players.
Use Werewolves, Seers, Madman, the Villagers.
According to the number of players, and then add Thief, Teru-Teru cards.

For the Werewolves : Survive without being executed.
For the Villagers : Kill the Werewolves.
For the Teru-Teru : Themselves are executed.

Thief "Kyle"

However, if the residents was the beast to be killed.
